Authors: Micael Ferreira Gonçalves, Ana Esteves, Artur Alves
Title:
Revealing the hidden diversity, opportunities and challenges
of marine fungi in Portugal with description of Paraconiothyrium
poriferum sp. nov.
Keywords:
Fungal Diversity, Didymosphaeriaceae, Marine Fungi,
Phylogeny, Taxonomy
Abstract:
Fungi are ubiquitous organisms with a wide range
distribution of almost all ecosystems on planet, including the marine
environments. Coastal and estuary ecosystems remain unexplored as fungal
habitats, potentially harboring a hidden diversity with important
ecological roles. During an extensive survey of marine fungi in coastal
and estuarine environments from Portugal a collection of 612 isolates
were obtained from water, algae, sponges and driftwood. The collections
yielded 117 taxa from 38 distinct genera, which were identified using
molecular methods. The most abundant taxa were Cladosporium
cladosporioides, Penicillium terrigenum, P. brevicompactum and Fusarium
equiseti/incarnatum complex. Fungal community composition ranged among
the host/substrate and between coastal and estuarine samples. The
occurrence of a high fungi diversity harboring some novel species was
disclosed. Through a multilocus phylogeny based on ITS, tub2 and tef1-α
sequences, in conjunction with morphological and physiological data we
proposed here Paraconiothyrium poriferum as a new species.
